awd_titl_txt: Promoting Engagement in Chemistry, Physics, and Earth Sciences
awd_abstract_narration:
Open universities enroll an increasing number of students, many of whom have not considered a career in one of the physical sciences. To serve as a model and advance knowledge, this project at Utah Valley University (UVU) will further develop the capacity of a comprehensive open enrollment university with a markedly different student population from those at research-focused institutions.  This project will attract, retain, and graduate students in the physical sciences and prepare them for science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) professions. The primary aims of the project are to: 1) promote student success and degree completion for academically promising students in the physical sciences of chemistry, earth science and physics at UVU through financial-needs-based scholarships; 2) prepare students for post-graduate education and careers by providing faculty-mentored research experiences and other support services aimed at enriching the education of scholars; 3) increase STEM enrollment and completion in an open-enrollment teaching institution with traditionally low enrollments in STEM disciplines; and 4) advance knowledge of evidence-based practices relative to faculty-mentored research. Questions of interest include (a) close examination of the evolution of student attitudes and abilities for doing science from their uncertain beginnings into those consistent with confident, STEM-career-committed graduates, and (b) the role played by the faculty mentor and student cohort in that process. Project research will focus on which programmatic factors most affect women and other underrepresented groups in STEM. Dissemination of results and research will include publications and presentations at appropriate venues and workshops on evidence-based best practices both locally and in regional discipline-specific educational conferences.

With funding from the National Science Foundation's Scholarships in Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics (S-STEM) program, over the course of five years this project will provide scholarships for full tuition and books to 50 academically talented and financially needy students in physics, chemistry and earth science baccalaureate degree programs. The interventions are grounded in evidence-based practices and focus on the most essential elements that affect student success. This project builds on the successful components of a Track 1 S-STEM project, including the strength of faculty mentors and student involvement in faculty-mentored research, participation in regional, national, and international conferences, and preparation for and acceptance to graduate school. Based on the evidence of the previous project, this program will ameliorate several institutionally-identified attrition points in the STEM educational pipeline including lengthy time to completion, excessive part-time work, and feelings of isolation by some women students. Exit interviews of students supported in the Track 1 project indicated that the program made a substantial difference in keeping them in school, expanding their vision of science, and giving them a stepping stone to success. It is expected that at the end of the project period at least 90% of students will have received a baccalaureate degree in the physical sciences or be on track to graduate on time.

por.por_cntn:
Utah Valley University (UVU) is primarily an undergraduate institution with  limited resources for advanced research in STEM fields. Enrollments in the physical sciences is small, despite a developing need for more STEM employees as part of a regional high tech boom. 

With this in mind, UVU is pleased to report the success of the NSF S-STEM program  "Promoting Engagement in Chemistry, Physics and Earth Sciences. The program has graduated 42 students over the last 5 years with physical science STEM degrees. An additional 9 students are on track to graduate in the near future.  Many of these students have gone on to graduate programs across the country, from coast to coast, while others opted for more immediate STEM opportunities in the local workforce as technicians, teachers,  researchers and IT workers. The program has produced 17 graduates in physics, 12 in chemistry and 13 in the geological and environmental sciences. 

A new cohort of approximately 15 students was selected annually in the first three years of the program  through an open and competitive process that involved faculty interviews and committee reviews. Additional students were selected over time to fill vacancies due to graduations or other departures. Each new NSF scholar was awarded full tuition and fees, plus up to $2000 per year in additional funds that could be used for other educational costs, including research, travel and living expenses. 

The success of the program hinged on close faculty mentoring. Each NSF scholar had their own facutly mentor and each mentor pledged to advise their mentee for the remainder of their education at UVU regardless of the student’s success in the NSF program.  Nearly all the students engaged in research and had the opportunity to present their work at regional and national conferences. Many presented multiple times at different venues. 

The array of research topics  covered by the students was vast, including investigations as varied as looking at the concentrations of arsenic in soils after forest fires, and examining the build up of pesticides and microplastics in local waterways and lakes, to characterizing the spectra of hundreds of thousands of galaxies in order to learn about the structure of the universe itself.

Some of the projects were highly cross disciplinary. For example, groups from both chemistry and physics had major projects for cancer detection. Students in these groups had opportunities that included the design and construction of optical laser scattering equipment, raman spectroscopy and ultrasound equipment along with various stages and mounts associated with them. Samples were prepared from tissue samples and cell cultures, measurements made and data analyzed. Computer codes were written to model data, control experiments and even produce AI codes that were then trained to recognized cancer cells among healthy ones by differences in their scattering properties. 

Other projects revolved around environmental issues such as examining the effects of urban heat islands or looking at the use of waterbirds' use of hot springs in the area through the winter.  

Many more projects revolved around more esoteric, but more traditional physical science studies, including such things on the 'small scale' as Bose-Einstein condensates, and nuclear magnetic resonance studies of novel molecules, while on the 'large scale' some students had the opportunity of studying the atmosphere of brown dwarf stars, and others in determining the distances to remote galaxies from Hubble Space Telescope data.  

Working in small research groups, the students formed cohesive, cooperative and productive groups. There were taught the modern methods of 'how to do science'. Such lessons are invaluable for the transition to graduate programs and STEM careers, instilling not only skills, but confidence in the students.  

Finally, gender equity in the physical science STEM fields has long been an issue, with substantially fewer women entering and graduating in them. Efforts were made in this program to bolster recruiting and retention of women scholars. A full one third of the participants in the program were women. While not at parity, a comparison cohort shows that this still represents a greater than average fraction of participation by women in these fields. The same comparison shows that women drop out of these fields at a much higher rate than men, but this is not true of this program in which the women succeeded at pace with the men. The added support of good faculty mentorship appeared to play a strong role in helping to avoid many of the pitfalls experienced women who find themselves in a pronounced minority in their programs. The primary lesson learned is simple: Get students involved in a research group with a good faculty mentor. This gives them a place to belong and a place to demonstrate their abilities. Given that, they will flourish.
